Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1246854
PI: Y. C. Lee (Univ. of Colorado)

Atomic layer deposition (ALD) and molecular layer deposition (MLD) are important thin film deposition processes based on sequential, self-limiting surface reactions. ALD and MLD can deposit conformal and ultrathin inorganic and organic films with atomic/molecular layer control. ALD was recognized as the transformative technology when ALD was added to the semiconductor roadmap over ten years ago. ALD and MLD have the potential to make an even more significant impact if their throughput and cost can be improved using roll-to-roll (R2R) processes. For example, ALD and MLD could be used to fabricate high quality gas diffusion barrier on polymers for organic light emitting diodes and thin film photovoltaics. ALD could also be employed to coat the electrodes of Li ion batteries to improve their capacity stability and greatly extend their lifetime. Laboratory results have already confirmed the excellent performance of ALD barriers and coatings. Transitioning these laboratory results to the market requires a rapid and cost-effective method to perform ALD and MLD on polymer or foil webs.

This project will build an R2R ALD/MLD testbed with process control for web speeds of up to 30 m/min. To accomplish this challenging goal, computational fluid dynamics modeling will be performed to understand ALD/MLD and support the systematic design of novel gas source heads for ALD/MLD on both flat and porous substrates. The gas source heads will be integrated with a R2R web handling machine and this new apparatus will be optimized using studies of in situ monitoring of thickness versus processing parameters. Reduced order models will be studied and applied to achieve optimal performance. In addition, new methodologies will be developed for web handling such as the placement of the gas source head in the region of web wrap on a roller. The interdisciplinary team will also work with ALD NanoSolutions, a local startup company. ALD NanoSolutions is currently developing an R2R ALD testbed to coat flat polymer web substrates. The team will also collaborate with the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Sandia Labs, Formosa Plastic and Kent Displays for potential scale-up manufacturing.

R2R ALD/MLD nano-manufacturing will facilitate the commercialization of ALD/MLD for a large number of applications and help to restore U.S. manufacturing competitiveness. This research will also educate and train undergraduate and graduate students to perform original research in scalable nano-manufacturing. A new section on ALD/MLD-enabled systems will be introduced into a first-year mechanical engineering projects course. These projects will develop designs that will be used in the K-12 outreach programs. R2R manufacturing teaching modules will be also introduced into existing undergraduate and graduate courses. The results of this research will also be widely disseminated at various scientific meetings and through a project web site.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atomic layer deposition (ALD) and molecular layer deposition (MLD) are important thin film deposition processes based on sequential, self-limiting surface reactions. ALD and MLD can deposit conformal and ultrathin inorganic and organic films with atomic/molecular layer control. ALD was recognized as the transformative change in transistor technology when it was introduced into semiconductor manufacturing in 2007. ALD and MLD will make an even more significant impact if their manufacturing throughputs and costs can be improved by orders of magnitude through roll-to-roll (R2R) processes. For example, ALD and MLD could be used to fabricate high quality gas diffusion barrier on polymers for organic light emitting diodes. ALD could also be employed as coating on electrodes of Li ion batteries to extend their lifetime in fast charging/discharging conditions. Laboratory results have already confirmed the excellent performance of ALD barriers and coatings. Transitioning these laboratory results to the market requires a rapid and cost-effective method to perform ALD and MLD on polymer or foil webs. This project was to build an R2R ALD/MLD system for web speeds of up to 30 m/min. We have developed such a system with a gas source head proven to be effective for web speeds of up to 50 m/min!

Working with our industry partner, ALD NanoSolutions, we have demonstrated the world’s first atmospheric R2R ALD with an in situ sensor for thickness control. Thickness distribution could deviate from the target value if there was undesirable chemical vapor deposition (CVD). From the study, we realized it was very challenging to eliminate CVD in atmospheric environment.  A new R2R ALD/MLD system has been developed with multiple output ports connected to soft vacuum enclosure. This novel approach was proven very effective for excellent R2R ALD/MLD.  In particular, porous substrates represented by anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) with pore diameters of 100nm and lengths of 25,000 nm were successfully deposited with ALD ZnO using the new system. In addition, we demonstrated that R2R ALD Al2O3 on LiCoO2 (LCO) battery electrodes at a speed of 50 meters/min could improve the capacity stability. More importantly, a specific R2R machine was established for R2R ALD/MLD with custom-designed soft vacuum enclosure and controlled tension, speed and temperature. This fully integrated, automated R2R ALD/MLD system is the most effective solution for porous substrates in the world.

To support the design, fabrication and characterization of the R2R ALD/MLD, we developed a new probabilistic model to replace commonly used random defect model. With this new model, we can accurately characterize fabrication yields with respect to different sample sizes. We have also demonstrated that ALD coatings could protect copper nanowires in boiling heat transfer; such protection removes reliability as a show-stopper in many nanostructure-enabled applications. As for integrated R2R ALD and MLD, we found out a a thick organic layer could encapsulate most of contaminants such as particles for a super-clean, planarized substrate. Indeed, R2R ALD coating’s defects were reduced by 10X after using R2R MLD for the encapsulation and planarization.

In addition, we have developed a novel analysis and design environment that allows key components to be optimized for efficient and spatially controlled transport and deposition of reactants. A unique simulation and topology optimization framework was created that describes the geometry of the components by the level set method and predicts the transport of reactants by a Navier-Stokes model, discretized by the extended finite element method. To simulate and optimize the transport of reactants into nano-structured materials, for example to coat particles in lithium ion batteries, we extended the optimization framework onto flows with finite Knudsen numbers. These flows can be modeled accurately by the Boltzmann transport equations with an immersed boundary formulation to account for finite Knusden effects. For the first time, we could solve flow and advective transport topology optimization problems accounting for finite Knudsen numbers.

We have disseminated research results effectively: 17 journal articles, 14 conference presentations, 10 keynote speeches, short course, seminars, or tutorials. As for training, the research studies have been conducted by 3 post-docs, 11 graduate students with 3 Ph.D. degrees awarded and 8 undergraduate research assistants. In addition, we have reached out to directly educate more than 200 college students and 50 K-12 students.  ALD NanoSolutions, our industry partner, is recognized as the world leader to commercialize ALD technologies for fast charging batteries. Forge Nano received a major investment in 2016 to expand its manufacturing capacity on ALD processes for batteries. Both companies have hired our post-docs. As for the government labs, National Renewable Energy Laboratory is sponsoring a post-doc to continue the project. Boulder, Colorado, is becoming a hub of innovative solutions to apply ALD/MLD for future batteries. R2R ALD/MLD is an enabling approach for these solutions. It should be noted that battery manufacturing is expected to be only one of the many applications enabled by R2R ALD/MLD. 

 


Last Modified: 12/04/2017
Modified by: Yung-Cheng Lee

Images (1 of )
  • A fully integrated R2R ALD/MLD (roll-to-roll atomic layer deposition/molecular layer deposition) system with the rotary deposition chamber connected to an R2R machine in a soft vacuum environment. It can deposit a nano-scaled coating on a porous LiCoO2 battery electrode at a speed of 50 m/min.
    University of Colorado Boulder and Texas A&M University
    Public Domain
    Yung-Cheng Lee
    R2R ALD/MLD
  • Normalized zinc signal versus distance from the top of porous anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) membrane with pore diameters ranging from 10 to 100 nm. A uniform ALD ZnO film is successfully grown in holes with an aspect ratio of 250 (25,000nm to 100nm).
    University of Colorado Boulder
    Public Domain
    Yung-Cheng Lee
    R2R ALD on Anodic Aluminum Oxide
  • Elemental maps on the LCO electrode: (a) Co, (b) C, (c) Al, and (d) mixture. The clear Al signal in the electrode confirms successful ALD coating at 50 RPM (50 m/min).
    University of Colorado Boulder
    Copyrighted
    Yung-Cheng Lee
    R2R ALD on LiCoO2 electrode
  • Discharge capacity versus discharge-charge cycle (1C rate) numbers are presented for uncoated LCO electrodes and LCO electrodes coated with 4 cycles of Al2O3 R2RALD. The R2R ALD is performed using 10, 25 and 50 RPM at 60 Â°C.
    University of Colorado Boulder
    Copyrighted
    Yung-Cheng Lee
    Li ion battery enhanced by R2R ALD
  • The world?s first atmospheric R2R ALD with an in situ sensor for thickness control is demonstrated by the team and the industry partner, ALD NanoSolutions. Thickness distribution can deviate from the target value if there is undesirable chemical vapor deposition (CVD).
    University of Colorado Boulder
    Public Domain
    Yung-Cheng Lee
    R2R ALD with a thickness sensor
  • A computation framework is developed to support the design and characterization of R2R ALD/MLD. This image shows the optimized design of a structure in a flow channel; the geometry of the structure is optimized to maximize the species flux between the solid and fluid at the fluid-solid interface.
    University of Colorado Boulder
    Copyrighted
    Yung-Cheng Lee
    Modeling for R2R ALD/MLD
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Atomic layer deposition (ALD) and molecular layer deposition (MLD) are important thin film deposition processes based on sequential, self-limiting surface reactions. ALD and MLD can deposit conformal and ultrathin inorganic and organic films with atomic/molecular layer control. ALD was recognized as the transformative change in transistor technology when it was introduced into semiconductor manufacturing in 2007. ALD and MLD will make an even more significant impact if their manufacturing throughputs and costs can be improved by orders of magnitude through roll-to-roll (R2R) processes. For example, ALD and MLD could be used to fabricate high quality gas diffusion barrier on polymers for organic light emitting diodes. ALD could also be employed as coating on electrodes of Li ion batteries to extend their lifetime in fast charging/discharging conditions. Laboratory results have already confirmed the excellent performance of ALD barriers and coatings. Transitioning these laboratory results to the market requires a rapid and cost-effective method to perform ALD and MLD on polymer or foil webs. This project was to build an R2R ALD/MLD system for web speeds of up to 30 m/min. We have developed such a system with a gas source head proven to be effective for web speeds of up to 50 m/min! Working with our industry partner, ALD NanoSolutions, we have demonstrated the world?s first atmospheric R2R ALD with an in situ sensor for thickness control. Thickness distribution could deviate from the target value if there was undesirable chemical vapor deposition (CVD). From the study, we realized it was very challenging to eliminate CVD in atmospheric environment. A new R2R ALD/MLD system has been developed with multiple output ports connected to soft vacuum enclosure. This novel approach was proven very effective for excellent R2R ALD/MLD. In particular, porous substrates represented by anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) with pore diameters of 100nm and lengths of 25,000 nm were successfully deposited with ALD ZnO using the new system. In addition, we demonstrated that R2R ALD Al2O3 on LiCoO2 (LCO) battery electrodes at a speed of 50 meters/min could improve the capacity stability. More importantly, a specific R2R machine was established for R2R ALD/MLD with custom-designed soft vacuum enclosure and controlled tension, speed and temperature. This fully integrated, automated R2R ALD/MLD system is the most effective solution for porous substrates in the world. To support the design, fabrication and characterization of the R2R ALD/MLD, we developed a new probabilistic model to replace commonly used random defect model. With this new model, we can accurately characterize fabrication yields with respect to different sample sizes. We have also demonstrated that ALD coatings could protect copper nanowires in boiling heat transfer; such protection removes reliability as a show-stopper in many nanostructure-enabled applications. As for integrated R2R ALD and MLD, we found out a a thick organic layer could encapsulate most of contaminants such as particles for a super-clean, planarized substrate. Indeed, R2R ALD coating?s defects were reduced by 10X after using R2R MLD for the encapsulation and planarization. In addition, we have developed a novel analysis and design environment that allows key components to be optimized for efficient and spatially controlled transport and deposition of reactants. A unique simulation and topology optimization framework was created that describes the geometry of the components by the level set method and predicts the transport of reactants by a Navier-Stokes model, discretized by the extended finite element method. To simulate and optimize the transport of reactants into nano-structured materials, for example to coat particles in lithium ion batteries, we extended the optimization framework onto flows with finite Knudsen numbers. These flows can be modeled accurately by the Boltzmann transport equations with an immersed boundary formulation to account for finite Knusden effects. For the first time, we could solve flow and advective transport topology optimization problems accounting for finite Knudsen numbers. We have disseminated research results effectively: 17 journal articles, 14 conference presentations, 10 keynote speeches, short course, seminars, or tutorials. As for training, the research studies have been conducted by 3 post-docs, 11 graduate students with 3 Ph.D. degrees awarded and 8 undergraduate research assistants. In addition, we have reached out to directly educate more than 200 college students and 50 K-12 students. ALD NanoSolutions, our industry partner, is recognized as the world leader to commercialize ALD technologies for fast charging batteries. Forge Nano received a major investment in 2016 to expand its manufacturing capacity on ALD processes for batteries. Both companies have hired our post-docs. As for the government labs, National Renewable Energy Laboratory is sponsoring a post-doc to continue the project. Boulder, Colorado, is becoming a hub of innovative solutions to apply ALD/MLD for future batteries. R2R ALD/MLD is an enabling approach for these solutions. It should be noted that battery manufacturing is expected to be only one of the many applications enabled by R2R ALD/MLD. Last Modified: 12/04/2017 Submitted by: Yung-Cheng Lee
